{"success":true,"issue":{"number":224,"title":"Epic: SBS Rewrite - From Prototype to First-Class Experience","state":"OPEN","labels":["ai-authored","feature:new","scope:architectural"],"url":"https://github.com/e-vergo/SLS-Strange-Loop-Station/issues/224","body":"## Overview

This epic tracks the transformation of SBS from a prototype to a first-class experience, addressing feedback from the Lean community:

- **Yaël Dillies**: Build times too long; wants to avoid context-switching between VSCode and browser. Suggested displaying stripped-down SBS HTML directly in the VSCode infoview panel.
- **Alex Kontorovich**: TeX and Lean should live in same file (PNT+ delimiter approach, confirmed offline)

**Core insight:** Feedback loop latency is the real pain point. The solution is aggressive caching + unified TeX/Lean model + IDE-ready backend.

## Caching Baselines

Preliminary caching results from the prototype (first successful run):

| Project | Cold Build | Cached | Rebuild % |
|---------|-----------|--------|-----------|
| GCR (57 nodes) | 42.9s | 13.2s | 69% |
| PNT (527 nodes) | 23.5 min | 17.9s | 98.7% |

These numbers validate Phase 1's priority and ground the success criteria below.

## Plan Document

Full implementation plan: [`dev/markdowns/living/REWRITE_PLAN.md`](https://github.com/e-vergo/Side-By-Side-Blueprint/blob/main/dev/markdowns/living/REWRITE_PLAN.md)

## Phases

### Phase 1: Caching Infrastructure (Highest Impact)
**Goal:** Reduce typical rebuild from ~5-7s to ~1-2s

- [ ] 1.1 Manifest hash cache for graph generation
- [ ] 1.2 Per-declaration content-addressed cache
- [ ] 1.3 SubVerso highlighting optimization
- [ ] 1.4 Asset pipeline optimization

### Phase 2: Unified TeX/Lean Model
**Goal:** Support both Lean-first and Paper-first workflows with validation

- [ ] 2.1 Delimiter-based statement embedding (PNT+ style `/-%%...%%-/`)
- [ ] 2.2 Statement-signature validation
- [ ] 2.3 Paper.tex bidirectional linking
- [ ] 2.4 Unified configuration

### Phase 3: IDE-Ready Backend
**Goal:** Infrastructure that enables VSCode extension without building it

- [ ] 3.1 Real-time artifact export
- [ ] 3.2 MCP extension for IDE queries
- [ ] 3.3 JSON schema stabilization
- [ ] 3.4 Editor decoration data

### Phase 4: VSCode Extension (Future)
Out of scope for this epic, but enabled by Phases 1-3.

## Success Criteria

### Quantitative
- Incremental rebuild < 1s (no Lean changes)
- Full rebuild < 4s (SBS-Test scale)
- Cache hit rate > 80% for typical development

### Qualitative
- Alex can use PNT+ delimiter workflow in SBS
- Yaël's dependency errors caught before full build
- New users can start with paper.tex and migrate to Lean-first
- VSCode extension has all data it needs

## Sub-Issues

### Wave 1: Quick Wins
- [ ] #225 - Manifest hash cache for graph generation (1.1)
- [ ] #226 - Asset pipeline optimization (1.4)
- [ ] #227 - Unified runway.json configuration (2.4)

### Wave 2: Core Caching
- [ ] #228 - Per-declaration content-addressed cache (1.2)
- [ ] #229 - JSON schema stabilization (3.3)

### Wave 3-5: (Issues to be created)
- Wave 3: Unified Model (2.1, 2.3)
- Wave 4: Validation (2.2, 3.1, 3.4)
- Wave 5: IDE Backend (1.3, 3.2)

## Context

- [Zulip announcement thread](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/113486-announce/topic/Side-by-side.20blueprint.20-.20Experience.20prototype)
- [Zulip discussion thread](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/536994-ecosystem-infrastructure/topic/Discussion.20thread.20-.20Side.20by.20Side.20blueprint)

{"success":true,"issue":{"number":225,"title":"Implement manifest hash cache for graph generation","state":"CLOSED","labels":["ai-authored","feature:new"],"url":"https://github.com/e-vergo/SLS-Strange-Loop-Station/issues/225","body":"## Overview

Part of #224 (SBS Rewrite Epic) - Wave 1, Item 1.1

## Problem

Graph generation via `extract_blueprint` costs 2-3s per build, even when nothing has changed.

## Solution

Hash `manifest.json` content and cache `dep-graph.json` + `dep-graph.svg`. Skip regeneration on cache hit.

### Cache Structure
```
.lake/build/dressed/.graph_cache/
├── {manifest_hash}.json    # cached dep-graph.json
└── {manifest_hash}.svg     # cached dep-graph.svg
```

### Implementation

In `dev/scripts/build.py`:
1. Compute SHA256 of manifest.json before graph generation
2. Check cache directory for matching hash
3. If hit: copy cached files, skip `extract_blueprint`
4. If miss: run normally, save to cache

## Files
- `dev/scripts/build.py`

## Success Metrics
- Graph-only changes: 2-3s → 0.1s (cache hit)

Part of #224 (SBS Rewrite Epic) - Wave 1, Item 1.4

## Problem

Asset copying (CSS/JS) costs 50-100ms per build, even when files haven't changed.

## Solution

Track asset file hashes and skip copy operations when unchanged.

### Implementation

In `dev/scripts/build.py`:
1. Track asset hashes in `.build_state.json`
2. Before copying, compare current hash against cached hash
3. Skip copy if identical
4. Update hash cache after successful copy

### Hash Tracking Structure
```json
// .build_state.json
{
  "asset_hashes": {
    "common.css": "abc123...",
    "graph.js": "def456...",
    "theme.js": "ghi789..."
  }
}
```

## Files
- `dev/scripts/build.py`

## Success Metrics
- CSS-only changes: 1-2s → 0.3s

## Problem

Currently separate configuration patterns for paper-first vs Lean-first workflows. No unified way to specify workflow mode or validation settings.

```json

  "workflow": "lean-first" | "paper-first" | "hybrid",

  "validation": {
    "statementMatch": true,
    "dependencyCheck": true,
    "paperCompleteness": true
  }
}
```

### Implementation

2. Update `dev/scripts/build.py` to respect workflow mode
3. Add sensible defaults (backward compatible)
4. Document configuration options

## Files

- Existing projects work without changes (defaults)

{"success":true,"issue":{"number":228,"title":"Implement per-declaration content-addressed cache","state":"CLOSED","labels":["ai-authored","feature:new"],"url":"https://github.com/e-vergo/SLS-Strange-Loop-Station/issues/228","body":"## Overview

Part of #224 (SBS Rewrite Epic) - Wave 2, Item 1.2

## Problem

Unchanged declarations are regenerated on every build, costing 50-100ms per declaration.

## Solution

Content-addressed caching keyed on declaration content hash.

### Cache Key Components
- Declaration fully qualified name
- `@[blueprint]` attribute fields (statement, proof, uses, etc.)
- Source span hash (file + line range)
- SubVerso version (highlighting may change between versions)

### Cache Structure
```
.lake/build/dressed/.decl_cache/
├── index.json              # label -> hash mapping
└── {content_hash}/
    ├── decl.json
    ├── decl.tex
    ├── decl.html
    └── decl.hovers.json
```

### Implementation

1. Create `toolchain/Dress/Dress/Cache.lean` with hash computation
2. Modify `Dress/Generate/Declaration.lean` to check cache before generation
3. If hit: symlink or copy from cache
4. If miss: generate normally, save to cache with hash

## Files
- `toolchain/Dress/Dress/Cache.lean` (new)
- `toolchain/Dress/Dress/Generate/Declaration.lean`

## Success Metrics
- Incremental builds skip unchanged declarations
- Cache hit rate > 80% for typical development

## Parent Epic
#224

Part of #224 (SBS Rewrite Epic) - Wave 2, Item 3.3

## Problem

Currently implicit schemas for `manifest.json`, `dep-graph.json`, and declaration artifacts. Breaking changes are invisible, and IDE extensions can't validate responses.

## Solution

Explicit JSON Schema definitions for all artifact formats.

### Schema Files
```
dev/schemas/
├── manifest.schema.json
├── dep-graph.schema.json
├── declaration.schema.json
└── events.schema.json
```

### Implementation

1. Document current artifact formats as JSON Schema
2. Add schema validation to build pipeline (optional check)
3. Version schemas for breaking change tracking
4. Generate TypeScript types for future VSCode extension

## Benefits
- IDE extension can validate responses
- Breaking changes are explicit and versioned
- Auto-generate TypeScript types for extension development
- Better documentation of data contracts

## Files
- `dev/schemas/` (new directory)
- `dev/scripts/build.py` (optional validation)

## Success Metrics
- All artifact formats have corresponding schemas
- Schemas validated against real build output
- TypeScript types generated and usable

#224

input_full.title: Audit Dress activation pathway for Lake integration
input_full.body:
## Context

Part of #224 (SBS Rewrite Epic) — **Crush 1: Foundation**, Track 1 (Dress Upstream Integration)

## Problem

Dress artifact generation currently requires a separate Lake build pass gated behind `BLUEPRINT_DRESS=1`. This prevents Lake's native incremental compilation from handling artifact caching and forces a redundant compilation cycle.

## Scope

Map the full activation pathway and assess integration feasibility:

1. **Trace the env-var gate:** How does `BLUEPRINT_DRESS=1` trigger `elab_rules` hooks in `Dress/Capture/ElabRules.lean`? What code paths are gated?
2. **Identify always-active requirements:** What must change to make Dress hooks fire during normal `lake build` without the env var?
3. **Lake compatibility:** Do artifact files (`.json`, `.tex`, `.html`) coexist cleanly with normal Lake build outputs in `.lake/build/`? Any clobber risks?
4. **Non-SBS impact:** If Dress hooks are always active, what happens when building a Lean project that has no `@[blueprint]` declarations? Must be zero-cost.
5. **Lakefile changes:** What `lakefile.lean` modifications are needed across SBS-Test, GCR, PNT?

## Deliverable

A written assessment (can be issue comment or doc) covering the 5 points above, with a recommended integration approach.

## Files

- `toolchain/Dress/Dress/Capture/ElabRules.lean` (elaboration hooks)
- `toolchain/Dress/Dress/Generate/Declaration.lean` (artifact generation)
- `dev/scripts/build.py` (current two-pass orchestration)
- `toolchain/SBS-Test/lakefile.lean`, `showcase/*/lakefile.lean`

## Parent Epic
#224 — Crush 1: Foundation

input_full.title: Integrate Dress into normal Lake build (eliminate separate pass)
input_full.body:
## Context

Part of #224 (SBS Rewrite Epic) — **Crush 1: Foundation**, Track 1 (Dress Upstream Integration)

Depends on the audit issue (T1-A).

## Problem

The current two-pass architecture (`lake build` then `BLUEPRINT_DRESS=1 lake build`) doubles compilation time and prevents Lake's incremental compilation from naturally handling artifact caching.

## Solution

Remove the env-var gate. Dress elaboration rules fire during standard `lake build`. Lake's own change detection handles incrementality — unchanged `.lean` files aren't recompiled, so their artifacts aren't regenerated.

### Implementation

1. Remove `BLUEPRINT_DRESS` env-var gating from elaboration hooks
2. Make Dress a lakefile dependency that activates via import (zero-cost when not imported)
3. Ensure artifacts land in a predictable, Lake-safe location
4. Update `build.py` to drop the separate Dress pass
5. Update lakefile configurations across all projects
6. Verify: `lake build` alone produces all artifacts that previously required the two-pass approach

## Success Criteria

- Single `lake build` produces all Dress artifacts
- No performance regression for non-SBS projects importing Dress
- Lake's `--no-build` correctly skips artifact generation when nothing changed
- `build.py` is simpler (one fewer phase)

## Files

- `toolchain/Dress/Dress/Capture/ElabRules.lean`
- `dev/scripts/build.py`
- `toolchain/SBS-Test/lakefile.lean`
- `showcase/*/lakefile.lean`

## Parent Epic
#224 — Crush 1: Foundation

input_full.title: Validate Lake-native incremental artifact behavior
input_full.body:
## Context

Part of #224 (SBS Rewrite Epic) — **Crush 1: Foundation**, Track 1 (Dress Upstream Integration)

Depends on Dress integration into normal Lake build (T1-B).

## Problem

After integrating Dress into the normal Lake build, we need confidence that Lake's incremental compilation correctly handles artifact generation — only regenerating what changed, never doing unnecessary work.

## Solution

Create a test suite that validates incremental behavior across common development scenarios.

### Test Cases

1. **No-op rebuild:** Run `lake build` twice with no changes. Second build should touch zero artifact files.
2. **Single declaration change:** Modify one `@[blueprint]` declaration. Only that declaration's artifacts should regenerate.
3. **New declaration:** Add a new `@[blueprint]` declaration. Only new artifacts should be generated, existing ones untouched.
4. **Deleted declaration:** Remove a `@[blueprint]` declaration. Artifacts should be cleaned up (or flagged stale).
5. **Statement-only change:** Modify only the `statement` field in `@[blueprint]`. Verify artifact regeneration is scoped correctly.
6. **Non-blueprint change:** Modify a `.lean` file with no `@[blueprint]` declarations. Zero artifact work should occur.
7. **Dependency chain:** Change a declaration that others depend on. Verify correct propagation.

### Implementation

- pytest-based test suite using SBS-Test as the project
- Each test: modify file → run `lake build` → check artifact mtimes/hashes → assert expectations
- Can extend the existing `sbs/tests/pytest/` framework

## Success Criteria

- All 7 test cases pass
- Tests run in CI (part of evergreen tier)

## Files

- `dev/scripts/sbs/tests/pytest/` (new test files)
- `toolchain/SBS-Test/` (test project)

## Parent Epic
#224 — Crush 1: Foundation

input_full.title: Profile SubVerso highlighting pipeline for optimization targets
input_full.body:
## Context

Part of #224 (SBS Rewrite Epic) — **Crush 1: Foundation**, Track 2 (SubVerso Live Performance)

## Problem

SubVerso highlighting takes 800-6500ms per declaration and accounts for 93-99% of total build time. For live infoview use, we need sub-200ms. Before optimizing, we need to know exactly where the time goes.

## Scope

1. **Instrument the pipeline:** Add timing to each phase of `Highlighted` construction in `forks/subverso/src/SubVerso/Highlighting/Code.lean`
2. **Measure per-phase costs:**
   - Info tree traversal and `InfoTable` construction
   - Hover data extraction
   - Token classification (`identKind`, `tacticInfo`, etc.)
   - HTML/JSON serialization
3. **Benchmark across projects:**
   - SBS-Test (33 nodes) — small declarations
   - GCR (57 nodes) — medium declarations with paper
   - PNT (591 annotations) — large declarations, complex proofs
4. **Identify the 80/20:** Which phases dominate? Are there outlier declarations?
5. **Memory profiling:** Is allocation pressure a factor?

## Deliverable

Profiling report with:
- Per-phase timing breakdown (median, p95, max)
- Top 10 slowest declarations with root cause
- Recommended optimization targets ranked by expected impact
- Baseline numbers to measure future improvements against

## Files

- `forks/subverso/src/SubVerso/Highlighting/Code.lean` (highlighting pipeline)
- `forks/subverso/src/SubVerso/Highlighting/InfoTable.lean` (indexed lookups)
- `toolchain/Dress/Dress/SubVersoExtract.lean` (integration layer)

## Parent Epic
#224 — Crush 1: Foundation

input_full.title: Statement completeness validator and basic LaTeX checking
input_full.body:
## Context

Part of #224 (SBS Rewrite Epic) — **Crush 1: Foundation**, Track 4 (Statement Validation)

## Problem

No validation ensures `@[blueprint]` declarations have well-formed statements. Missing or malformed LaTeX statements are silently accepted, producing broken output downstream.

## Solution

Add validation at elaboration time (Lean diagnostics, not post-build).

### Checks

1. **Completeness:** Every `@[blueprint]` declaration must have a non-empty `statement` field. Missing → warning.
2. **LaTeX well-formedness:**
   - Balanced braces `{}`
   - Balanced math delimiters `$ $`, `\[ \]`
   - No undefined LaTeX commands (configurable allowlist)
3. **Character encoding:** Flag non-UTF8 or problematic characters in statements.

### Integration

- Runs during elaboration as Lean diagnostics (warnings in Problems panel)
- Suppressible via `@[blueprint skipValidation := true]` or similar
- Zero runtime cost when validation passes (no expensive parsing)

## Success Criteria

- Missing statement → Lean warning at the `@[blueprint]` attribute site
- Unbalanced braces → Lean warning with location
- Valid statements → no diagnostics (zero noise)
- Existing projects (SBS-Test, GCR, PNT) produce no spurious warnings

## Files

- `forks/LeanArchitect/Architect/Attribute.lean` (attribute processing)
- `forks/LeanArchitect/Architect/Validation.lean` (new)

## Parent Epic
#224 — Crush 1: Foundation

tool_calls.input_summary: {"title": "Optimize SubVerso highlighting critical paths for sub-200ms", "body": "## Context\n\nPart of #224 (SBS Rewrite Epic) \u2014 **Crush 2: Performance + Infoview**, Track 2 (SubVerso Live Perfo...

input_full.title: Optimize SubVerso highlighting critical paths for sub-200ms
input_full.body:
## Context

Part of #224 (SBS Rewrite Epic) — **Crush 2: Performance + Infoview**, Track 2 (SubVerso Live Performance)

Depends on profiling results from #245.

## Problem

SubVerso highlighting takes 800-6500ms per declaration. For live infoview use, we need sub-200ms for typical declarations and sub-500ms for large ones.

## Solution

Attack the top bottlenecks identified by profiling (#245). Likely optimization targets:

### Probable Candidates

1. **Info tree traversal:** The O(n) containment search in `allInfoSorted` may dominate for large declarations. Consider interval tree or binary search on sorted spans.
2. **Hover data extraction:** Computing hover content for every token is expensive. Batch or defer hover computation.
3. **HTML string generation:** String concatenation in Lean is O(n²). Consider builder pattern or pre-allocated buffers.
4. **Redundant classification:** `identKindCache` helps within a declaration, but classifying shared stdlib types is repeated across declarations.

### Approach

- Profile-guided: only optimize what the data shows is slow
- Benchmark before/after each change against the same declaration set
- Regression tests: highlighting output must be byte-identical before and after optimization

## Success Criteria

- Median per-declaration highlighting < 200ms (SBS-Test scale)
- P95 < 500ms (GCR scale)
- Max < 1500ms (PNT outliers)
- Zero rendering regressions

## Files

- `forks/subverso/src/SubVerso/Highlighting/Code.lean`
- `forks/subverso/src/SubVerso/Highlighting/InfoTable.lean`

## Parent Epic
#224 — Crush 2: Performance + Infoview

tool_calls.input_summary: {"title": "Lazy and incremental SubVerso highlighting for live use", "body": "## Context\n\nPart of #224 (SBS Rewrite Epic) \u2014 **Crush 2: Performance + Infoview**, Track 2 (SubVerso Live Performan...

input_full.title: Lazy and incremental SubVerso highlighting for live use
input_full.body:
## Context

Part of #224 (SBS Rewrite Epic) — **Crush 2: Performance + Infoview**, Track 2 (SubVerso Live Performance)

Depends on critical path optimization (T2-B).

## Problem

Even with optimized critical paths, live infoview use requires highlighting to feel instant. Full upfront computation doesn't match the interaction model — users look at one declaration at a time.

## Solution

Shift from eager full-declaration highlighting to lazy, incremental computation.

### Strategies

1. **Lazy hover computation:** Compute hover content on-demand when the user actually hovers, not upfront for every token. Store position → info mapping, defer rendering.
2. **Partial re-highlighting:** When a declaration changes, identify which syntax nodes actually changed and only re-process those. Reuse highlighting for unchanged subtrees.
3. **Progressive refinement:** Return basic syntax highlighting immediately (keywords, strings, comments). Enhance with semantic tokens (types, tactics, proofs) asynchronously.
4. **Shared type info pool:** Standard library types (Nat, List, Prop, etc.) are highlighted identically across declarations. Build a shared pool on first encounter, reuse everywhere.

### Architecture Decision

This may require changes to how SubVerso's `Highlighted` type works — currently it's a complete, immutable structure. The lazy approach needs it to be incrementally constructible.

## Success Criteria

- Initial highlight response < 50ms (basic syntax)
- Full semantic highlighting < 200ms (async, non-blocking)
- Hover data computed in < 10ms per hover event
- Memory usage doesn't grow unboundedly with shared pool

## Files

- `forks/subverso/src/SubVerso/Highlighting/Code.lean`
- `toolchain/Dress/Dress/SubVersoExtract.lean`

## Parent Epic
#224 — Crush 2: Performance + Infoview

input_full.title: Fork Lean infoview: setup and minimal SBS panel
input_full.body:
## Context

Part of #224 (SBS Rewrite Epic) — **Crush 2: Performance + Infoview**, Track 3 (Lean Infoview Fork)

## Problem

SBS blueprint data (status, statement, dependencies) is invisible during normal Lean development. Users must context-switch to a browser to see blueprint information. Yaël Dillies identified this as a primary friction point.

## Solution

Fork the Lean infoview to add an SBS panel directly in VSCode.

### Scope (Minimal Viable Fork)

1. **Fork `lean4` and/or `lean4-infoview`** — determine minimal fork surface:
   - Can we modify only `lean4-infoview` (React app) and add custom RPC calls?
   - Or do we need Lean server changes to expose blueprint data?
   - Evaluate Lean's [user widgets](https://lean-lang.org/lean4/doc/examples/widgets.html) as a lighter alternative before committing to full fork
2. **Add "Blueprint" tab** in the infoview panel, alongside Goals/Messages/etc.
3. **Placeholder content** — display raw JSON from the nearest `@[blueprint]` declaration when cursor is inside one
4. **Build and distribution** — verify the fork builds, works as a drop-in VSCode extension replacement

### Fork Maintenance Strategy

- Minimize diff from upstream Lean
- Document all modified files for future rebasing
- Track upstream Lean releases for compatibility

## Success Criteria

- "Blueprint" tab appears in VSCode infoview

- Fork builds reproducibly from CI

- Integration: `toolchain/Dress/Dress/Load.lean` (data access patterns)

input_full.title: Wire SBS blueprint data to infoview via Lean RPC
input_full.body:
## Context

Part of #224 (SBS Rewrite Epic) — **Crush 2: Performance + Infoview**, Track 3 (Lean Infoview Fork)

Depends on infoview fork setup (T3-A).

## Problem

The infoview fork has a Blueprint tab but needs real data. During elaboration, Dress has access to all blueprint metadata in the Lean environment. This data needs to flow to the infoview.

## Solution

Expose blueprint data through Lean's RPC mechanism so the infoview React app can query it.

### Data to Expose

For the declaration at cursor position:
- **Status:** One of the 6 statuses (notReady, ready, sorry, proven, fullyProven, mathlibReady)
- **Statement:** LaTeX text from the `statement` field
- **Dependencies:** List of labels this declaration `uses`
- **Dependents:** List of labels that reference this declaration
- **Proof state:** Has proof? Has sorry? Fully proven?
- **Metadata:** Description, reference, comments

### Implementation Options

1. **Custom RPC endpoint:** Register a new RPC method in the Lean server that queries `Dress/Load.lean` functions to extract blueprint data from the environment
2. **Environment extension:** Store blueprint data in Lean's persistent environment so it's queryable via standard mechanisms
3. **File-based bridge:** Dress writes artifacts; infoview reads them from disk (simpler but higher latency)

Option 1 is recommended — it's the standard Lean pattern for infoview data.

### Query Pattern

```
Cursor position → Find enclosing declaration → Look up @[blueprint] node → Return structured data
```

## Success Criteria

- Blueprint tab shows real status, statement, and dependencies for `@[blueprint]` declarations
- Data updates when cursor moves between declarations
- Latency < 50ms for RPC query (data is already in environment)
- Graceful degradation: non-blueprint declarations show nothing

## Files

- Lean server fork (new RPC handler)
- `toolchain/Dress/Dress/Load.lean` (environment queries)
- `lean4-infoview` fork (React consumer)

## Parent Epic
#224 — Crush 2: Performance + Infoview

input_full.title: Heuristic statement-signature cross-referencing and diagnostics
input_full.body:
## Context

Part of #224 (SBS Rewrite Epic) — **Crush 2: Performance + Infoview**, Track 4 (Statement Validation)

Depends on basic statement validator (#249).

## Problem

A well-formed LaTeX statement can still be semantically wrong — it might describe a different theorem than the Lean declaration it's attached to. There's no mechanism to detect drift between the LaTeX and Lean worlds.

## Solution

Heuristic cross-referencing that catches obvious mismatches. Not full semantic equivalence — a smoke test.

### Matching Strategy

1. **Extract Lean signature components:**
   - Quantified variables and their types
   - Hypothesis names and types
   - Conclusion type
   - Key mathematical identifiers (function names, type names)

2. **Extract LaTeX statement components:**
   - Mathematical symbols and identifiers
   - Quantifier-like phrases ("for all", "there exists")
   - Key structural elements (implications, conjunctions)

3. **Cross-reference rules:**
   - Every named type in the Lean signature should have a plausible LaTeX counterpart
   - Quantifier count should roughly match
   - If the Lean declaration has `n` hypotheses, the LaTeX should have comparable structure
   - Flag if declaration name appears nowhere in the statement (common oversight)

### Diagnostics

- Surface as Lean warnings (visible in Problems panel AND the new SBS infoview)
- Severity: `warning` (not error — heuristic matches aren't perfect)
- Suppressible per-declaration: `@[blueprint skipCrossRef := true]`

## Success Criteria

- Catches deliberately mismatched statement/declaration pairs in test suite
- < 5% false positive rate on existing projects (SBS-Test, GCR, PNT)
- Zero false positives on correctly matched pairs

## Files

- `forks/LeanArchitect/Architect/Validation.lean` (extends from #249)
- `toolchain/Dress/Dress/Generate/Declaration.lean` (signature extraction)

## Parent Epic
#224 — Crush 2: Performance + Infoview

input_full.title: LaTeX rendering in Lean infoview SBS panel
input_full.body:
## Context

Part of #224 (SBS Rewrite Epic) — **Crush 3: Polish + Live Dev**, Track 3 (Lean Infoview Fork)

Depends on SBS data wiring (#253).

## Problem

The infoview Blueprint tab displays raw LaTeX text for statement fields. Users need rendered mathematical notation to verify statements match their intent.

## Solution

Render LaTeX statements as formatted mathematics directly in the infoview.

### Options

1. **KaTeX in React** (recommended) — Lightweight, fast, runs client-side in the infoview's React app. Supports the LaTeX subset commonly used in `@[blueprint]` statements. ~300KB bundle addition.
2. **MathJax in React** — Full LaTeX support but heavier (~1MB). Overkill for the subset we need.
3. **Pre-rendered HTML from Dress** — Dress generates HTML during elaboration. Infoview displays it directly. Avoids client-side LaTeX processing but couples infoview to build artifacts.

### Implementation (KaTeX approach)

1. Add KaTeX as a dependency to the `lean4-infoview` fork
2. Create a `<LaTeXStatement>` React component
3. Parse and render the `statement` field from RPC data
4. Handle rendering errors gracefully (show raw LaTeX on failure)
5. Support the LaTeX commands commonly used in `@[blueprint]` statements

### LaTeX Subset

The `@[blueprint]` statement field typically uses:
- Standard math mode (`$...$`, `\[...\]`)
- Common commands: `\forall`, `\exists`, `\in`, `\subset`, `\to`, `\mapsto`
- AMSmath environments: `align`, `cases`, `pmatrix`
- Custom macros from project `.tex` preambles (needs macro injection support)

## Success Criteria

- LaTeX statements render as formatted math in the Blueprint tab
- Rendering latency < 20ms per statement (KaTeX is fast)
- Graceful fallback: malformed LaTeX shows raw text + warning
- Custom macros from project preamble are supported

## Files

- `lean4-infoview` fork (React components)
- KaTeX integration

## Parent Epic
#224 — Crush 3: Polish + Live Dev

input_full.title: Interactive navigation and status display in infoview SBS panel
input_full.body:
## Context

Part of #224 (SBS Rewrite Epic) — **Crush 3: Polish + Live Dev**, Track 3 (Lean Infoview Fork)

Depends on LaTeX rendering (#T3-C) and data wiring (#253).

## Problem

The Blueprint tab shows data but isn't interactive. Users can't navigate dependencies, see the dependency context, or interact with proof status — they still need the browser for that.

## Solution

Add interactive features to the infoview Blueprint panel that replace the need to context-switch to the browser for common operations.

### Features

1. **Status color indicators:**
   - Display the declaration's blueprint status using the 6-status color model
   - Color dot + status label (e.g., 🟢 proven, 🔴 sorry)
   - Consistent with the colors in `Dress/Graph/Svg.lean` and `common.css`

2. **Dependency navigation:**
   - List `uses` declarations as clickable links
   - Click → navigate to that declaration's source location in the editor
   - Show dependency direction (upstream/downstream)
   - Display each dependency's status color

3. **Mini dependency graph:**
   - Small DAG visualization showing the current declaration and its immediate neighbors
   - Nodes colored by status
   - Click to navigate
   - Consider using a lightweight React graph library (dagre, elkjs)

4. **Collapsible proof display:**
   - Show/hide proof text for the current declaration
   - Syntax highlighted (using SubVerso data)
   - Useful for reviewing proofs without scrolling

5. **Metadata panel:**
   - Description, reference, comments from `@[blueprint]` fields
   - Links to external references (paper sections, Mathlib PRs)

## Success Criteria

- Clicking a dependency navigates to its Lean source
- Status colors match the 6-status model exactly
- Mini graph renders in < 100ms for typical dependency neighborhoods
- All features degrade gracefully when data is unavailable

## Files

- `lean4-infoview` fork (React components)
- Graph visualization library integration

## Parent Epic
#224 — Crush 3: Polish + Live Dev

input_full.title: Watch mode and incremental site regeneration
input_full.body:
## Context

Part of #224 (SBS Rewrite Epic) — **Crush 3: Polish + Live Dev**, Track 5 (Live Development Experience)

Depends on Dress Lake integration (#247) — artifacts must be generated incrementally by Lake for watch mode to be useful.

## Problem

Every change requires manually re-running `build.py`. There's no way to get automatic site regeneration when artifacts change.

## Solution

A watch mode that monitors for changes and triggers only the necessary regeneration phases.

### Watch Targets

| Change Type | Action |
|------------|--------|
| `.lean` source | Lake handles recompilation + artifact regeneration. Watch detects new/changed artifacts in `.lake/build/dressed/` |
| CSS/JS assets | Copy only changed assets to `_site/` |
| Runway templates | Full page regeneration (rare, acceptable) |
| Graph topology change | Re-layout graph (new/removed edges) |
| Status-only change | Recolor graph nodes in-place (no layout recalc) |
| `runway.json` | Full rebuild |

### Implementation

1. **File watcher:** Python `watchdog` library monitoring:
   - `.lake/build/dressed/` for artifact changes
   - `dress-blueprint-action/assets/` for CSS/JS
   - Runway template directory
2. **Change classifier:** Determine which regeneration phase is needed based on what changed
3. **Incremental Runway:** Regenerate only affected pages when possible
4. **Graph intelligence:** Distinguish topology changes (require layout) from status changes (just recolor)

### CLI Integration

```bash
sbs watch --project SBSTest   # Watch and regenerate
sbs dev --project SBSTest     # Watch + regenerate + serve (combined with T5-B)
```

## Success Criteria

- Artifact change → site regeneration in < 2s
- CSS change → visible in browser in < 1s
- No unnecessary full rebuilds
- Clean shutdown on Ctrl+C

## Files

- `dev/scripts/sbs/commands/watch.py` (new)
- `dev/scripts/sbs/build/` (incremental regeneration logic)
- `dev/scripts/build.py` (optional integration)

## Parent Epic
#224 — Crush 3: Polish + Live Dev

input_full.title: Dev server with WebSocket live reload
input_full.body:
## Context

Part of #224 (SBS Rewrite Epic) — **Crush 3: Polish + Live Dev**, Track 5 (Live Development Experience)

Depends on watch mode (T5-A).

## Problem

After site regeneration, the user must manually refresh the browser. The feedback loop should be: edit → save → browser updates automatically.

## Solution

A dev server that serves `_site` and pushes live reload events via WebSocket.

### Implementation

1. **HTTP server:** Serve `_site/` directory (extend existing `sbs serve`)
2. **WebSocket endpoint:** `/ws` endpoint for live reload messages
3. **Client injection:** Inject a small `<script>` into served HTML pages that connects to the WebSocket and reloads on message
4. **Integration with watch mode:** When the watcher (T5-A) detects a site change, send a reload message to all connected browsers
5. **Smart reload:** For CSS-only changes, hot-reload stylesheets without full page refresh

### CLI

```bash
sbs dev --project SBSTest --port 8000
# Equivalent to: sbs watch + sbs serve + live reload
```

### Technical Choices

- Use Python's `http.server` + `websockets` library (lightweight, no framework needed)
- Script injection via response middleware (don't modify actual `_site` files)
- Debounce rapid changes (50ms) to avoid reload storms

## Success Criteria

- `sbs dev` serves the site and watches for changes in a single command
- Browser auto-refreshes within 500ms of site regeneration completing
- CSS-only changes hot-reload without full page refresh
- Multiple browser tabs supported (all receive reload)
- Clean shutdown on Ctrl+C

## Files

- `dev/scripts/sbs/commands/dev.py` (new, combines watch + serve + reload)
- `dev/scripts/sbs/commands/serve.py` (extend for WebSocket)

## Parent Epic
#224 — Crush 3: Polish + Live Dev

input_full.command:
gh issue edit 224 --body "$(cat <<'EPICEOF'
## Overview

This epic tracks the transformation of SBS from a prototype to a first-class experience, addressing feedback from the Lean community:

- **Yaël Dillies**: Build times too long; wants to avoid context-switching between VSCode and browser. Suggested displaying stripped-down SBS HTML directly in the VSCode infoview panel.
- **Alex Kontorovich**: TeX and Lean should live in same file (PNT+ delimiter approach, confirmed offline)

**Core insight:** Feedback loop latency is the real pain point. The solution is aggressive caching + unified TeX/Lean model + IDE-ready backend.

## Architectural Vision

The end state is a single-pass build where Dress artifacts are generated live during Lake's normal type-checking, SubVerso highlights in under 200ms, and a forked Lean infoview displays blueprint data (status, statement, dependencies) directly in VSCode. The browser-based site regenerates incrementally via watch mode with live reload.

```
Edit .lean
  → Lake incremental recompile (Dress hooks always active)
    → SubVerso highlights in <200ms
    → Artifacts generated live
    → Infoview shows SBS panel (status, statement, deps)
  → Runway incrementally regenerates affected pages
  → Dev server live-reloads browser
```

**Caching strategy:** Lake-native incrementality is the primary caching mechanism. Custom caching is reserved for global operations (graph layout, manifest, site generation) handled by Waves 1-2.

## Caching Baselines

Preliminary caching results from the prototype (first successful run):

| Project | Cold Build | Cached | Rebuild % |
|---------|-----------|--------|-----------|
| GCR (57 nodes) | 42.9s | 13.2s | 69% |
| PNT (527 nodes) | 23.5 min | 17.9s | 98.7% |

These numbers validate Wave 1's priority and ground the success criteria below.

---

## Completed Work

### Wave 1: Quick Wins ✅
- [x] #225 - Manifest hash cache for graph generation (1.1)
- [x] #226 - Asset pipeline optimization (1.4)
- [x] #227 - Unified runway.json configuration (2.4)

### Wave 2: Core Caching ✅
- [x] #228 - Per-declaration content-addressed cache (1.2)
- [x] #229 - JSON schema stabilization (3.3)

### Wave 3: Unified Model ✅
- [x] Delimiter-based statement embedding (2.1)
- [x] Paper.tex bidirectional linking (2.3)

---

## Remaining Work: Task Crushes

The remaining features are organized into three intensive work sessions (crushes), structured around a dependency graph of five tracks.

### Track Overview

| Track | Focus | Key Challenge |
|-------|-------|---------------|
| **T1: Dress Upstream** | Eliminate separate build pass, Lake handles incrementality | Lake compatibility, zero-cost for non-SBS |
| **T2: SubVerso Performance** | Sub-200ms highlighting for live infoview use | Deep optimization of info tree traversal |
| **T3: Lean Infoview Fork** | SBS panel in VSCode with status, statement, dependencies | Fork maintenance, RPC design, LaTeX rendering |
| **T4: Statement Validation** | Catch drift between LaTeX statements and Lean declarations | Heuristic matching without full semantic equivalence |
| **T5: Live Dev Experience** | Watch mode, incremental site regen, live reload | Change classification, WebSocket integration |

### Dependency Graph

```
Track 1 (Dress upstream) ──┐
                            ├──→ Track 3 (Infoview fork)
Track 2 (SubVerso perf)  ──┘

Track 4 (Validation) ── independent, can start anytime
Track 5 (Dev experience) ── depends on Track 1 (incremental artifacts)
```

---

### Crush 1: Foundation

Build the foundation: integrate Dress into Lake's normal build pipeline, profile SubVerso for optimization targets, and add basic statement validation.

**Tracks:** T1 (Dress Upstream) + T2-A (SubVerso Profiling) + T4-A (Basic Validation)

| Issue | Track | Title |
|-------|-------|-------|
| #246 | T1 | Audit Dress activation pathway for Lake integration |
| #247 | T1 | Integrate Dress into normal Lake build (eliminate separate pass) |
| #248 | T1 | Validate Lake-native incremental artifact behavior |
| #245 | T2 | Profile SubVerso highlighting pipeline for optimization targets |
| #249 | T4 | Statement completeness validator and basic LaTeX checking |

**Deliverable:** Single-pass `lake build` produces all artifacts. SubVerso profiling data identifies optimization targets. Basic statement validation catches missing/malformed LaTeX.

---

### Crush 2: Performance + Infoview

Optimize SubVerso to sub-200ms, stand up the forked Lean infoview with real SBS data, and add heuristic statement cross-referencing.

**Tracks:** T2-B/C (SubVerso Optimization) + T3-A/B (Infoview Fork + Data Wiring) + T4-B (Cross-Referencing)

| Issue | Track | Title |
|-------|-------|-------|
| #250 | T2 | Optimize SubVerso highlighting critical paths for sub-200ms |
| #251 | T2 | Lazy and incremental SubVerso highlighting for live use |
| #252 | T3 | Fork Lean infoview: setup and minimal SBS panel |
| #253 | T3 | Wire SBS blueprint data to infoview via Lean RPC |
| #254 | T4 | Heuristic statement-signature cross-referencing and diagnostics |

**Deliverable:** SubVerso highlights typical declarations in <200ms. VSCode infoview shows blueprint status, statement, and dependencies for the declaration at cursor. Validation catches obvious statement/declaration drift.

---

### Crush 3: Polish + Live Dev

Complete the infoview experience with LaTeX rendering and interactive navigation. Add watch mode and live reload for the browser-based site.

**Tracks:** T3-C/D (Infoview Polish) + T5 (Live Dev Experience)

| Issue | Track | Title |
|-------|-------|-------|
| #255 | T3 | LaTeX rendering in Lean infoview SBS panel |
| #256 | T3 | Interactive navigation and status display in infoview SBS panel |
| #257 | T5 | Watch mode and incremental site regeneration |
| #258 | T5 | Dev server with WebSocket live reload |

**Deliverable:** LaTeX statements render as formatted math in the infoview. Users can click dependencies to navigate. `sbs dev` watches for changes and live-reloads the browser.

---

## Success Criteria

### Quantitative
- Incremental rebuild < 1s (no Lean changes)
- Full rebuild < 4s (SBS-Test scale)
- SubVerso highlighting < 200ms median, < 500ms p95
- Infoview RPC query < 50ms
- Site regeneration < 2s after artifact change

### Qualitative
- Alex can use PNT+ delimiter workflow in SBS
- Yaël sees blueprint data directly in VSCode without browser context-switch
- Dependency errors caught before full build
- New users can start with paper.tex and migrate to Lean-first
- Statement/declaration drift caught automatically

## Context

- [Zulip announcement thread](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/113486-announce/topic/Side-by-side.20blueprint.20-.20Experience.20prototype)
- [Zulip discussion thread](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/536994-ecosystem-infrastructure/topic/Discussion.20thread.20-.20Side.20by.20Side.20blueprint)

---

# Retrospective: Epic #224 Waves 4-7 Scoping

## What happened
Scoped the remaining features for the SBS Rewrite Epic (#224). Waves 1-3 were already complete (caching infrastructure, unified TeX/Lean model, delimiter embedding + bidirectional linking).

The user provided a key architectural insight: instead of treating caching as a separate concern, move Dress upstream into Lake's normal build so Lake's native incremental compilation handles artifact caching. Combined with the ambition to fork Lean's infoview for direct IDE integration and optimize SubVerso for sub-200ms live highlighting, this reframed the entire remaining work.

## Decisions made
1. **Lake-first caching:** Lake's incremental compilation is the primary caching strategy. Custom caching only for global operations (graph, manifest, site).
2. **Full stack ambition:** Dress in Lake + Lean infoview fork + SubVerso live performance (sub-200ms).
3. **5 tracks, 3 crushes, 14 issues:** Decomposed into Foundation → Performance + Infoview → Polish + Live Dev.

## Issues created
- Crush 1: #245 (SubVerso profiling), #246 (Dress audit), #247 (Dress integration), #248 (incremental validation), #249 (statement validator)
- Crush 2: #250 (SubVerso optimization), #251 (lazy highlighting), #252 (infoview fork), #253 (RPC wiring), #254 (cross-referencing)
- Crush 3: #255 (LaTeX rendering), #256 (interactive navigation), #257 (watch mode), #258 (live reload)

## What went well
- Deep codebase exploration before decomposition grounded the plan in reality (existing infrastructure, actual gaps)
- User's architectural reframe (Lake-first caching, Dress upstream) was caught and incorporated immediately
- IO captured: well-researched decomposition process was recognized as effective

## What to improve
- First issue creation batch failed due to invalid labels — should have checked available labels upfront
- Original decomposition (Waves 4-5 from the issue) was superseded by the architectural reframe — the scoping pivoted mid-conversation which was appropriate but worth noting

# L3 Meta-Analysis: Session Patterns

## Ingestion Summary
7 findings from cross-session analysis. Key patterns:

### Process Effectiveness
- **Explore-first decomposition** produces high-quality user alignment. The pattern of deep codebase exploration → structured decomposition → user feedback → issue creation was validated this session (user IO: "well researched and thought out").
- **Mid-conversation architectural pivots** are healthy. The shift from original Wave 4-5 structure to Lake-first architecture happened naturally when the user surfaced the "move Dress upstream" insight. The decomposition adapted cleanly.

### Tool Usage Patterns
- **Label validation gap:** Issue creation failed on first attempt due to non-existent labels. Checking `gh label list` before batch creation would prevent this. Low cost, high reliability improvement.
- **Parallel issue creation** works well — 5 issues created per batch with no conflicts.

### Orchestration Health
- Session stayed at orchestrator level throughout (no agent spawning needed for pure planning/scoping work). Correct per CLAUDE.md — orchestrator plans, agents implement.
- IO capture integrated naturally into the workflow without interrupting flow.

### Improvement Opportunities Surfaced
1. Add label validation to `sbs_issue_create` MCP tool (or pre-flight check)
2. The Explore agent provided excellent infrastructure context — consider making "explore before decompose" a standard pattern for `/task` alignment phase
3. AskUserQuestion with Architecture/Scope headers produced efficient decision points

input_full.body:
## Overview

Findings from L3 meta-analysis of session patterns. These are process and tooling improvements identified through cross-session introspection.

## Findings

### Tool Reliability
- #260 — Add label pre-validation to `sbs_issue_create`

### Process Patterns
- #261 — Standardize "explore before decompose" in `/task` alignment phase

input_full.title: Add label pre-validation to sbs_issue_create MCP tool
input_full.body:
## Context

Part of #259 (L3 Process Improvements). Origin: label validation failure during batch issue creation in Epic #224 scoping session.

## Problem

`sbs_issue_create` fails the entire issue creation if any label doesn't exist on the repo. During batch creation of 5 issues, 4 failed because `area:sbs:dress` and `area:devtools:testing` don't exist. This wasted a round-trip and required manual label lookup + retry.

## Solution

Add a pre-flight label check to `sbs_issue_create`:

1. Cache the repo's label list on first call (or periodically)
2. Before creating an issue, validate all requested labels exist
3. If invalid labels found, either:
   - **Option A:** Strip invalid labels and proceed with valid ones + warning
   - **Option B:** Fail fast with a clear message listing invalid labels and suggesting alternatives (fuzzy match against existing labels)

Option B is preferred — failing explicitly is better than silently dropping labels.

## Files

- `forks/sbs-lsp-mcp/src/sbs_lsp_mcp/sbs_tools.py`

input_full.title: Standardize explore-before-decompose pattern in /task alignment
input_full.body:
## Context

Part of #259 (L3 Process Improvements). Origin: observed high-quality plan output when deep codebase exploration precedes task decomposition.

## Observation

During Epic #224 scoping, spawning an Explore agent to investigate all 5 features' existing infrastructure before decomposing into issues produced a plan the user called "well researched and thought out." The pattern:

1. Spawn Explore agent with specific questions per feature
2. Agent reports: what exists, what's missing, key files, risk level
3. Orchestrator synthesizes into structured decomposition
4. User validates and reshapes

This was ad-hoc. It should be standard.

## Proposal

Update `/task` alignment phase to include an explicit "explore" step when the task involves architectural planning or multi-feature scoping:

1. Detect when a task is scoping/planning (vs. direct implementation)
2. Automatically spawn Explore agent to survey relevant infrastructure
3. Use exploration results to ground the decomposition in reality
4. Present findings alongside proposed decomposition

This could be encoded in the `/task` skill definition or in CLAUDE.md as a documented pattern.

## Files

- `.claude/agents/sbs-developer.md` or `CLAUDE.md` (pattern documentation)
- Potentially `forks/sbs-lsp-mcp/src/sbs_lsp_mcp/skills/task.py` (if automated)

input_full.title: Standardize L3 findings → GitHub issues as default behavior
input_full.body:
## Context

Part of #259 (L3 Process Improvements). Origin: user had to explicitly request that L3 findings be logged as issues — this should be automatic.

## Problem

L3 introspection produces findings (ingestion phase) and a synthesis summary (archive phase), but the findings are only recorded in the archive entry. They aren't surfaced as actionable GitHub issues unless the user explicitly asks.

## Proposal

Make the L3 `archive` phase automatically:

1. Create an epic issue summarizing the L3 cycle's findings
2. Create individual issues for each actionable finding
3. Link individual issues to the epic
4. Apply `origin:self-improve` label to all

This should be the default behavior of `sbs_introspect(level=3, phase="archive")`. The summary_content parameter already contains the synthesis — it should also trigger issue creation.

### Guard Rails

- Only create issues for findings that are clearly actionable (not observations)
- De-duplicate against existing open issues (check titles/labels)
- Cap at ~5 issues per L3 cycle to avoid issue spam
- Always apply `origin:self-improve` for traceability

## Files

- `forks/sbs-lsp-mcp/src/sbs_lsp_mcp/skills/introspect.py`

## Parent Epic
#259

input_full.title: Document AskUserQuestion header taxonomy effectiveness
input_full.body:
## Context

Part of #259 (L3 Process Improvements). Origin: observed that structured AskUserQuestion calls with standard headers (Architecture, Scope, Confirm) produced efficient decision points.

## Observation

CLAUDE.md defines a header taxonomy for AskUserQuestion (Confirm, Scope, Approach, Select, etc.). During the Epic #224 scoping session, questions using `Architecture` and `Scope` headers with 2-3 options each led to fast, clear decisions. The user selected options without needing "Other" in all cases.

Key patterns that worked:
- **Binary architecture decisions** with concrete implications described per option
- **Scope confirmation** after presenting a decomposition
- **Not asking** when the user gave clear direction (rejected one AskUserQuestion, corrected inline)

## Proposal

1. Add `sbs_question_stats` analysis to the standard L2 self-improve discovery phase
2. Track which headers and option counts lead to fastest resolution
3. Document effective patterns in CLAUDE.md's AskUserQuestion section
4. Consider adding "rejection analysis" — when users reject AskUserQuestion, what signal does that give?

## Files

- `CLAUDE.md` (documentation update)
- L2 discovery phase (analysis integration)
